that delivers premium Japanese

straight from Japan to your door.
Every box has a new theme,
and this month's is sakura season,

so the snacks are inspired
by cherry blossoms.

If you want to taste

- [Alvin] Hello there, welcome
back to another episode

This is a potato.

Today I'm gonna be taking a
look at making the roast beef

in one of my favorite personal
anime, "Attack on Titan."

The first thing I'm starting
with is a peasant loaf

which seems to be accompanying
the beef on the table.
In the bowl of a stand mixer,
I'm combining bread flour, salt, yeast,

and after giving the
dry ingredients a mix,
I'm following up with some water

and setting that on a
mixer at very low speeds.

So while everybody's
kinda becoming friends,

I like to stop the
process every now and then

and use the dough hook
to scrape down the sides

so that the flour does not
get a chance to escape.
And with the magic of a stand mixer,

this is gonna slowly turn into
a ball, which is kinda cool
'cause I really don't have to do anything.
I can just wait here.
I could chat with the homies,
I could check my email,

or I could just walk away and
let this thing do its thing.

Once the stand mixer
has done its job though,
I'm gonna oil up a container

and use a bowl scraper to get
the dough out of the mixer

and into its little greasy
bedroom in one solid piece.

In this little box, the
dough ball's gonna have
enough space and quiet to proof up nicely.
Peace out, little dude.

So here I am, furiously grating
ginger for our ginger beer
that is gonna wash down the whole meal.

My hands hurt, so I
asked Kendall to step in.

She's gonna help out,
and thank you, Kendall.

And after that we have
Steve. Steve is grating...
Oh, he dropped that. All right.
Here you go, don't drop it again.
Oh, you did it again.
Everybody, say hello to Steve.

He's the newest member of
the "Anime with Alvin" team

and we could not be happier
that he is behind the camera
and not grating ginger.
Oh, hey. What's up, Andrew?
Thanks for stepping in as well.

I really appreciate the little
relay race we got going on,

'cause I've been playing
too many video games
and my hands have been hurting.
And while all of this has been happening,
I've been simmering ginger slices
in a simple syrup in this little pot,

which after straining,
turns into ginger syrup.

Hooray! Now that we've made
the syrup, we're just...

Hey! Who keeps putting
my food like this, huh?

Was it you, Steve? I'm
gonna roll these lemons.
Wait, uh, cut the video. Cut the...
After cutting the lemons in half,

I'm gonna run them
through a full body press
in this citrus torture device.
Now that's a lotta juice.

Into a large glass vessel
with an airtight container,

we're gonna combine the
lifeblood of two lemons

with the precious, painstakingly
grated ginger from before.
After swirling them around a bit,

you'll notice that it'll
start to turn pink.
So naturally I went to Google,
and someone who's smarter than me

told me that this was a
product of anthocyanin,
a compound found in new ginger,
reacting to the acid in the lemon juice,
AKA it turns pink and nothing's wrong.

After filling this
vessel almost to the top
with some clean distilled water,
I'm adding in some champagne yeast.

This is gonna cause the
fizzly, bubbly thing
that we all like in ginger beer to happen.
Uh, there is a hole in this container.

I thought this was not
supposed to have a hole.

We're gonna insert this
plastic thing into the hole.
After a little love tap by Kendall,
I was told that this device uses water

as a way to prevent air
or bacteria from entering,

but allows the beer to
expel any air outwards.

Here I am, clearly
fascinated by this device.
Just imagine burping,

except it was one way
and you can't breathe in.
Goodbye, beer. Go burp over there.

I'm not sure what the
bread was doing back there,
but it looks like it's inhaled
an entire Costco rotisserie chicken,

so I'm gonna have to transfer
this into a larger vessel

where I can have a little
bit more room to do...
Ooh, ooh.
Now that's a good bread.

Here I am, folding each
corner of the bread
over its opposite side,

kinda like a four-way
diaper/mozzarella ball situation.
This allows the smooth side to face up.

And now it goes in the
back for a final proof.

I was getting kinda lonely
up here making all this food,

so I decided to make a little
bread friend for myself.
I think I'll name you Sascha.

She'll keep me company while
I unveil the star of the show,

a three-bone, 30 day
dry-aged prime rib roast.
This is such a beautiful piece of meat
that it should only be brought out
on the most wonderful of occasions,

or as your last meal before
you go fight some Titans
and probably lose.

It makes sense that this
meat would be dry-aged,
because in the world of "Attack on Titan,"
meat was very scare so it had to be cured
and probably hung for a while

before they could even
bring it out to eat.
Anyway, since this is dry-aged,
I am trimming off a lot of the fat cap

and a lot of those funky
areas that you can't eat.
One thing that I like to do with the fat
that is near the cap at the bottom
is to sorta give it a cross-hatch pattern.

This allows the fat to render
more and allows the seasoning
to penetrate that little fatty area.

Now, this is a beautiful
but huge piece of meat,

so the amount of salt
and pepper I'm gonna need

to even begin to season this
roast is going to be a lot.
I'm setting it on a wire rack over a tray
so that the airflow can circulate

completely around the meat,
drying out the exterior

and allowing for a better
crust to form faster.
In order for the salt to work its magic,

I'm leaving this uncovered in
the fridge for a whole day.
I'm gonna make a simple vegetable stew
to accompany the beef,

but before we can begin, we
need to chop the vegetables.
Now that the vegetables have been chopped,
it's time to make the stew.
After heating a little bit of neutral oil
in a pot over high heat,

I'm throwing in the
whites of the leeks first

to sort of get them translucent
and a little bit tender
before adding in the other vegetables.

This includes carrots,
parsnips, and potatoes,

and we're adding the
vegetables at different times

because each vegetable is
cooked and cut differently.
After enjoying the aroma
of sizzling vegetables for a little bit,

I'm adding in a good
amount of vegetable stock
to serve as the liquid for this stew.

Once the root vegetables show
no resistance when stabbed,
just like me, that means it's time
to add the broccoli and the mushrooms.
We're adding these two vegetables last
because they cook the fastest,
so after stirring a little bit,
giving a little bit of taste,

and seasoning with some
more salt and pepper,
the stew's pretty much ready.

After the beef has been
hanging out in the fridge
for about 24 hours at least,
a lot of cool things have happened.

The color, as you can see,
is a very deep, dark red.
The salt initially pulls water out,
but after dissolving into the water,
the saltwater goes back in,
seasoning the meat more thoroughly.

What's left is a deep, rich,
beautifully dry exterior

which is essentially begging
to be thrown into the oven
and turned into a golden brown crust.
So after sticking my probe inside,
I will gladly do what the beef commands.
Since this piece of beef is so large,

I'm gonna be using the
reverse sear technique,
which means I'm cooking it lower
at around 275 first for a few hours,

and then finishing it high at
around 500 degrees Fahrenheit

to get that nice and
beautiful crackly crust.
While the beef slow roasts in the oven
for just a little bit longer,

I'm gonna get up to some
more bread shenanigans.

Uh, as you can see, I'm
having quite the trouble

holding onto this piece
of parchment paper.
Oh, there...
Yeah, and it's on the ground.

So after wildly flailing
around for a little bit more,

I'm able to finally get the
bread onto its baking sheet,

followed by some
not-so-great scoring marks,
but, you know, it's a peasant loaf.
I don't think they really cared about that
when they had Titans to fight.
And into a very hot oven the bread goes.
And after filling the studio
with that really good fresh bread smell,

it emerges: a golden brown,
crusty loaf of bread,

perhaps foreshadowing for
how the beef might turn out.
And without further ado,

the beef makes its grand
reentrance into the stage.

However, even though
it is completely cooked

all the way through and
registers a nice 120,
we still gotta give it that nice,
beautiful golden crust jacket at the end.
So I'm brushing it with the beef drippings

that naturally came off during
that first cooking process,

so that way it'll really give
the beef a really nice crust.
And a ton of flavor as well.
It's almost unfair if you think about it.
The best part about prime rib
is that spice crust that everybody loves,
so I'm adding a little bit more seasoning

and some pepper on top, and
back into the oven it goes,
500 degrees for a couple of minutes.

If I could wolf whistle, I'd
be doing that all day right now
'cause this smells amazing.

The fat is sizzling. The
flavors are just so aromatic.
(sighs) Man.
I really wish Sascha could see this.

I totally understand why the
Scouts in "Attack on Titan"
went so crazy after seeing this meat.
It's beautiful, it's golden, it's...

It's an event, and if
I was about to go fight
some man-eating Titans out there,

I'd probably wanna eat
something like this beforehand.
So as the beef rests,
because it is still very, very, very hot,

we're gonna plate it up
like they did in the show.
So we're gonna use some butter lettuce,

the fanciest kinda stuff,
to kinda lay down a base.
And our vegetable stew, our peasant loaf,
and our hard-made ginger beer in the back.

Just please hold while I
make everything look good.
And there we have it,

the final meal presented
to the Scout Regiment

the night before they fought
valiantly on the battlefield.
The thing that's scaring me the most
is if I actually cooked this right,
so let's just cut it open and see.
I now await judgment from the steak gods.
Now that's looking pretty good!
The center is nice and pink.
The crust is a little more done
than I personally would've liked,

but the only thing that matters
is: how does this taste?
Yep.
That's a good piece of beef.
I was actually more curious
about how the bread and the stew tasted,

because that seemed like
something the soldiers

in "Attack on Titan" would
eat on a more regular basis.
It is also very good!
The bread is nice and fluffy and soft.

The stew is flavorful and the
vegetables add a nice touch,

definitely giving you
the energy and stamina
necessary to fight on the battlefield.

And because all the
soldiers are basically kids,
this beer is non-alcoholic.
It is also very good.

And because wine is pretty
common in that universe,

I decided to make my personal
recipe for red wine sauce
that I use for steaks.
Honestly, pairing these two together,

I think this meal would've
made Sascha very, very proud.

Don't mind me, I'm just

for a little bit and...
Ooh! Ow, I think I cut myself.
Oh no! Oh, no.
No, no, no, no! I didn't, I didn't...
Aw, come on! I was eating!
No, no, no! Stop!

Thanks again to our friends at Bokksu
for sponsoring this episode.
Bokksu provides authentic Japanese snacks
that you can't really find anywhere else,
which I really appreciate,

especially during a time when
people can't travel to Japan
as easily as they'd like.
The theme this month is sakura season,
and as you can see, the box is packed

with limited edition cherry
blossom-themed snacks.

The cherry blossoms in
Japan are beautiful.
People sometimes celebrate

by gathering under the
trees and having picnics.

A lot of the snacks are
flavored with cherry blossoms
and use a lot of the components,
such as this rice cracker,
which is savory, delicious, and crunchy,

and this mochi, which is chewy,
floral, and not too sweet.
